Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.647 - Northern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.647 - Northern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.En.647 - Northern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.En Chaco Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: precipitación estacional El bsq (2) se encuentra sobre suelos mal drenados, con textura limo-arcillosa.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los Bsq (1) estan inundados o saturados estacionalmente y alcanzan alturas entre los 15-18 m. Los Bsq (2) son bajos asociados a matorrales, el dosel es cerrado y su altura llega a los 3,6 m y algunos elementos dispersos de hasta 15 m.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq inundables del Chaco, 2. Bsq bajos Los bosques (1) en la parte mas humeda del Chaco al noreste de Argentina y Paraguay, Los bosques (2) se presentan al norte del Chaco en Argentina, Bolivia y Paraguay.

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.En.647 - Northern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Argentina

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Argentina
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.4.En.647 - Northern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland' macrogroup in Argentina.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- NT.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Paraguay
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.4.En.647 - Northern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland' macrogroup in Paraguay.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os EN -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of recent changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of CR -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of NT -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.648 - Northern Chaco Riparian Shrubland & Woodland EN (VU -- EN)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.648 - Northern Chaco Riparian Shrubland & Woodland EN (VU -- EN)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.En.648 - Northern Chaco Riparian Shrubland & Woodland' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.En Chaco Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Crecen en suelos arcillosos o limo-arcillosos, se inundan varios meses del año.

Biotic-processes.Summary: En general, son bosques densos, normalmente dominados por Albizia inundata.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq ribereños, 2. Bsq. semi-caducifolios, 3. Bsq siempreverdes Los Bsq (1) se encuentran en las llanuras de inundación de los rios Parapety y Paraguay en Bolivia, el resto se encuentra en Paraguay y norte de Argentina.

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.649 - Northern Chaco Palm Swamp EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.649 - Northern Chaco Palm Swamp EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.En.649 - Northern Chaco Palm Swamp' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.En Chaco Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Se desarrollan sobre suelos alcalinos que se saturan, de textura fina limo-arcilloso, se distribuyen en depresiones topograficas inundables.

Biotic-processes.Summary: En general, son bosques semi-abiertos y semi-densos, dominados por la palma (Copernicia alba) asociados con varios arboles higrófilos y arbustales.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq de palma Se distribuyen al norte del Chaco en Bolivia, Paraguay y Argentina.

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.En.649 - Northern Chaco Palm Swamp' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of NT -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.650 - Southern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland NE'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.En.650 - Southern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland NE'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.En.650 - Southern Chaco Floodplain Forest & Woodland' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.En Chaco Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Presentan una baja diversidad floristica en comparacion con los bosques de las llanuras de inundación del norte, presentan una diferencia de especies con las del sur. Estos bosques se pueden inundar temporalmente en epoca de lluvias

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq bajos del Chaco Se encuentran en las llanuras aluviales del Chaco Austral en Argentina

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
